column1: == Geography ==

The city is located 197 kilometres (122 miles) southeast of Zagreb and at an elevation of 96 metres (315 feet). It developed at the strategically important crossing over the Sava river toward Brod in Bosnia and Herzegovina. The Bosnian city was called Bosanski Brod until 2009.
Slavonski Brod is an important intersection of the Posavina part of the highway and a railway junction
column2: since it is located on the highway linking Zagreb–Lipovac–Belgrade (E70
column3: A3) and the Zagreb–Vinkovci–Belgrade railway. The ship port "Brod" on the Sava river is under construction.

column1: There is also a new modern highway under construction
column3: which will connect Northern Europe and Hungary with Croatia (through the region of Slavonia)
column4: and Bosnia and Herzegovina with Croatia (through the coastal region of Dalmatia). The alignment of this highway is approximately at a 19 km (12 mi) distance from the center of the town. With the completion of this route
column5: the area of the town Slavonski Brod will become one of the major highway intersections in this part of Europe connecting directions West-East and North-South.

column1: === Roman period ===
The first historical settlement in Brod dates from Roman times

column3: lodging for the night or an actual settlement.The Peutinger map refers to Marsonia as Marsonie

column1: === Before the Yugoslav breakup ===
The Slavs settled in the area of the city in the 6th century. The name of the town is mentioned for the first time in Bela IV of Hungary's charter
column2: dated 1224. The Vukovac fortress was built in the 15th century
column3: subsequently damaged by the Turks. The Ottoman Empire controlled the settlement from 1536 until 1691
column4: when it was ceded to the Empire of Austria
column5: as confirmed by the Treaty of Karlowitz in 1699. Until 1918
column6: Brod (named Brood before 1850) remained in the Austrian monarchy (Kingdom of Croatia-Slavonia after the compromise of 1867)
column8: under the administration of the Brooder Grenz-Infanterie-Regiment N°VII until 1881. A huge Vauban type fortress was built east of Vukovac.

column1: Alongside its defence role the city saw steady development of crafts and commerce. The education and culture were strongly dominated by the Franciscans. The 20th century was a period of strong economic growth of the city
column2: with the 1920s being called "the Golden Age of Brod". The city's current name dates from 1934 when it was changed from Brod na Savi.

column1: From 1941 to 1945 the city was part of the Independent State of Croatia. The town was heavily bombed by the Allies in 1944 and 1945. The bombing resulted in damage to 80% of the buildings in Slavonski Brod. The bombing resulted in 897 civilian deaths
column3: 208 wounded civilians
column4: and 28 military wounded in Slavonski Brod and Bosanski Brod.In 1990 democratic reforms legalised the formation of political parties other than the League of Communists of Croatia. In Slavonski Brod
column5: the first parties formed were the Croatian Democratic Union and the Croatian Democratic Party.
